From a defensive standpoint, you've got to keep him from controlling the game and monopolizing the game. That's what we have to try and do with Aaron Rodgers . He's a great player. He can create, improvise with his feet, go to his second and third choice in the route because he has such a quick release. The 6-foot-5, 241-pound Ben Roethlisberger isn't as speedy as Aaron Rodgers or Michael Vick nor as statuesque as Tom Brady and Peyton Manning ; he just makes it work. be planning to do will affect Rochester directly. Barack Obama Kirsten Gillibrand really hopes to hear that the research and development tax credit will be made permanent. She said that could bring many jobs here to Rochester. What that tax credit is about is it allows businesses that are innovators, entrepreneurial businesses like a lot of the businesses in Rochester to invest in research in development and get a credit for that investment. So really it makes a difference in creating jobs, particularly in growing industries like high tech, bio-tech, energy technology, optical technology all of that work that we do in Rochester would really benefit greatly from an R&D tax credit that's permanent. . In March, when the New York Times reported on the fracturing relationship between Apple and Google, Steve Jobs declined to comment. Eric Schmidt , meanwhile, was anything but cold, calculating, and distant. I continue to believe, as many do, that Steve Jobs is the best CEO in the world today, and I admire Apple and Steve Jobs enormously, Eric Schmidt declared. Is Schmidt-and, by extension, Google-tough enough to stay on top in tech? People have been asking this question about Google for years, but rarely has it mattered as much as it does
